Create a virtual accountability partner: To overcome the feeling of jealousy, consider creating a virtual accountability partner. This could be someone you know or a stranger who shares similar goals and interests. Set up regular check-ins with your partner to share your progress, discuss challenges, and offer support and encouragement. By doing so, you'll have someone to turn to for motivation and accountability, which can help you stay focused and motivated.

Break tasks into smaller, manageable chunks: When you feel overwhelmed by the progress of others, try breaking your tasks into smaller, more manageable chunks. This can help you avoid feeling overwhelmed and allow you to focus on one task at a time. For example, if you're trying to finish a large project, break it down into smaller tasks like researching, outlining, drafting, and editing. By doing so, you'll be able to make steady progress and avoid feeling like you're falling behind.

Practice gratitude: Jealousy can often stem from a sense of inadequacy or dissatisfaction with one's own progress. To combat this, try practicing gratitude. Take time each day to reflect on the things you're thankful for, such as your strengths, skills, and accomplishments. This can help shift your focus away from what others have and towards what you have, and can help you cultivate a more positive mindset.

Set realistic goals and celebrate small victories: When you're feeling jealous of others' progress, it can be helpful to set realistic goals for yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. By setting achievable goals, you'll be able to make steady progress and feel a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction. For example, if you're trying to finish a writing project, set a goal to write a certain number of words each day or week. By doing so, you'll be able to track your progress and feel a sense of accomplishment as you reach your goals.
